subject: RE: [junit] EJB Testing Strategies
msgSnippet: ...  If you face difficulty in testing your application, J2EE or otherwise, consider refactoring to a design more suitable to testing.  (Of
messageBody:
> What strategies have people successfully employed for testing
> business/workflow methods of a stateless session bean that
> has CMP entity beans at the back-end ?

<broken-record>
If you face difficulty in testing your application, J2EE or otherwise,
consider refactoring to a design more suitable to testing. (Of course,
it's advisable to have some tests to support your refactoring).
</borken-record>

Thus, I design EJBs such that they almost exclusively rely on one or
more non-EJB classes to do work. For example, my latest component
includes a message-driven bean (MDB). The MDB instantiates a few
objects that together parse the message (XMLReader, ContentHandler,
etc.). A Map of parsed values is then obtained from the ContentHandler.
This Map is passed to an object that interprets the contents of the Map
and performs some work. The results of the work are captured in a
result object that acts as a Collecting Parameter (a design pattern from
_Smalltalk Best Practices_ by Kent Beck, I believe). The result object
is passed to a communicator object whose job it is to create a response
message and send it. Thus, I have, for example, ResultTestCase,
CommunicatorTestCase, etc. Finally, I'm confident that these classes
will perform as expected when the MDB uses them.

Good luck,
Craig
